The Ultimate Outdoor Research Helium Rain Jacket Guide: Expert Review & Buying Guide 2024

After testing the Outdoor Research Helium Rain Jacket across multiple seasons and comparing it against top competitors, I'll share everything you need to know about this polarizing ultralight rain shell. Whether you're planning a thru-hike, need emergency weather protection, or seeking the perfect balance of weight and performance, this comprehensive guide will help you make an informed decision. Explore our complete outdoor gear collection for more essential hiking equipment.

Table of Contents

  • Helium Rain Jacket Overview
  • My Real-World Experience
  • Detailed Performance Analysis
  • User Reviews Summary
  • Pros and Cons
  • Best Alternatives
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Final Verdict

Helium Rain Jacket Overview

The Outdoor Research Helium Rain Jacket represents the pinnacle of ultralight rain gear design, targeting backpackers, climbers, and outdoor enthusiasts who prioritize weight savings above all else. This minimalist shell promises waterproof protection in a package that weighs less than most smartphones, but does it deliver on its promises?

Key Specifications

Weight: 6.3-6.8 oz (179-193g)

Fabric: Pertex Shield Diamond Fuse 2.5L

Denier: 30D ripstop nylon

Price: $170-180 MSRP

Packability: Stuffs into chest pocket

Features: Hood, elastic cuffs, drawcord hem

Built with bluesign-approved Pertex Shield Diamond Fuse 2.5-layer fabric and 30-denier ripstop construction, the outdoor research helium rain jacket promises durability despite its featherweight design. The jacket features fully taped seams, YKK Aquaguard zippers, and an adjustable hood designed to fit over helmets for alpine use.

Check Current Price on Amazon

What sets the Helium apart from heavier rain jackets is its philosophy of minimal features for maximum weight savings. You won't find pit zips, multiple pockets, or luxurious linings here—this is pure function over comfort, designed for those who count every ounce in their pack.

My Real-World Experience

I've been testing the Outdoor Research Helium Rain Jacket for over two years across diverse conditions—from the humid Appalachian Trail to the dry Rockies, and from weekend backpacking trips to multi-day alpine climbs. Here's what I've learned through real-world use.

First Impressions and Initial Testing

When I first pulled the Helium from its stuff sack, I was immediately struck by how thin and delicate it felt. The 2.5-layer construction gives it a plasticky feel that's quite different from the soft liner found in 3-layer jackets. The fit is deliberately trim—I normally wear a Large in outdoor gear, but the Helium Large provides just enough room for a base layer and lightweight fleece.

Performance in Light Rain

During a September hike in New Hampshire's White Mountains, I encountered my first real test: a sudden afternoon thunderstorm. For the first 30 minutes, the jacket performed admirably, shedding water effectively while I took shelter under a large pine. The hood stayed put in moderate wind, and I remained dry underneath. This is where the Helium shines—brief, intense showers where you need quick protection.

The Breathability Challenge

However, my experience took a turn during a humid July backpacking trip in the Smoky Mountains. Even in moderate rain, the lack of ventilation became apparent within minutes. The interior felt clammy and sticky against my skin, and condensation buildup was significant. I found myself alternating between getting rained on or sweating profusely—the classic rain gear dilemma amplified by the Helium's minimal breathability.

Ranger's Tip

A park ranger in Olympic National Park advised me to size up if planning to use the Helium for extended periods. The extra room helps with ventilation and reduces the clammy feeling against skin. I wish I'd learned this earlier in my testing.

Durability Lessons Learned

After 18 months of use, my Helium shows expected wear patterns. The DWR coating has diminished significantly, requiring regular reapplication of waterproofing treatments. I've experienced one small puncture from a thorny bush in Colorado, but the ripstop construction prevented it from tearing further. The zipper remains smooth, though the pull cord on the hem developed some fraying.

The most valuable lesson from my extended testing: the Helium Rain Jacket excels as an emergency shell and performs well in specific conditions, but it's not the versatile, all-weather solution some might expect from a "rain jacket." Understanding its limitations is crucial for successful use.

Detailed Performance Analysis

Waterproofing Performance

The Helium's waterproofing story is complex. The Pertex Shield Diamond Fuse membrane is technically waterproof with a 20,000mm hydrostatic head rating, but real-world performance depends heavily on DWR (Durable Water Repellent) coating maintenance. Fresh out of the box, light to moderate rain beads up and rolls off effectively. However, the thin 30-denier face fabric allows for faster DWR degradation compared to heavier shells.

In my testing, helium rain jacket performance begins to decline after approximately 40-50 hours of use or 3-4 wash cycles. Users in humid environments or those encountering frequent precipitation will need to reapply DWR treatment monthly to maintain optimal performance.

Breathability and Comfort

Critical Limitation

Breathability is the Helium's most significant weakness. The 2.5-layer construction with direct membrane contact creates a clammy, uncomfortable experience during any sustained activity. Users frequently report feeling like they're wearing a "plastic bag."

The absence of pit zips or other ventilation features compounds this issue. During testing at various intensities, I found the jacket becomes uncomfortable within 15-20 minutes of moderate activity, even in cool temperatures. This makes it unsuitable for any high-output activities like trail running or technical climbing where you can't easily shed layers.

Weight and Packability Excellence

Where the Helium truly excels is weight and packability. At 6.3-6.8 ounces depending on size and version, it's among the lightest fully-featured rain jackets available. The jacket stuffs into its own chest pocket (left hand pocket for women's version) and compresses to roughly the size of a large orange. This makes it ideal for ultralight backpacking where every ounce matters.

Fit and Design Features

The athletic cut prioritizes weight savings over layering versatility. The hood features a single rear adjustment point and is helmet-compatible, though movement feels restricted when cinched over headgear. Elastic cuffs seal effectively but can feel tight during extended wear. The hem drawcord allows for customization but lacks the refinement found in more expensive shells.

Women's Helium Rain Jacket on Amazon

Durability Assessment

The 30-denier ripstop construction strikes a reasonable balance between weight and durability for an ultralight shell. It's more robust than competitors like the Montbell Versalite (10D) but less durable than traditional hiking rain jackets. Users report good puncture resistance thanks to the ripstop weave, but abrasion resistance is limited. The women's outdoor research helium rain jacket shows similar durability characteristics with slightly different pocket configuration.

User Reviews Summary

After analyzing hundreds of user reviews from Amazon, REI, Reddit, and outdoor forums, clear patterns emerge. The Helium Rain Jacket is notably polarizing—users either love it for specific applications or hate it for failing to meet their expectations.

Positive Reviews

ZiggyySobo (7 months ago): "I'm a backpacker and this is one of my favorite pieces of kit in my pack. Lightweight, stops the wind, great way to regulate core temp with zipper action."

Jacob F (3 months ago): "This is a good ultralight rain jacket for spring through early fall... truly is waterproof and can fit into the back pocket of a pair of jeans quite easily."

Bryan S (2 months ago): "I've been carrying this jacket daily during a multi-week trip through Italy, and it's earned its place in my pack... kept me dry without overheating."

Critical Reviews

Steve (8 months ago): "15 min in light rain and drops were soaking through. It's like they forgot the DWR or something. Seems to be a common issue."

BriMo7 (8 months ago): "REI, please stop carrying this product. It is 100% NOT waterproof and maybe not even water resistant."

Anonymous (5 months ago): "This is an expensive windbreaker not a rain coat... I was soaked. What an embarrassing product."

Balanced Reviews

Mrksky (4 months ago): "I bought 3 helium jkts, use Nikwax to re-waterproof. These types of UL jkts loose proofing by washing or sweat oil. This is a great product."

Reddit User: "Depends. Okay for desert, bad choice for sustained rain."

ChrisAU: "Wore it for about 8-9 hours packing out a bull in a blizzard last fall. Stayed dry... doesn't look like its ever been worn."

Review Patterns and Key Insights

  • Geographic Trends: Users in dry western climates report better experiences than those in humid eastern regions
  • Activity Type: Emergency use and short-duration wear receive positive feedback; extended use generates complaints
  • Maintenance Factor: Users who regularly reapply DWR treatment report better long-term performance
  • Sizing Issues: Many recommend sizing up for better comfort and reduced condensation
  • Price Sensitivity: Positive reviews often mention getting the jacket on sale; negative reviews frequently cite poor value at full price

Pros and Cons

Pros

  • Ultra-Lightweight: At 6.3-6.8oz, among the lightest waterproof jackets available
  • Exceptional Packability: Compresses to orange-size in its own pocket
  • Effective for Light Rain: Performs well in brief showers and drizzle
  • Excellent Windproofing: Blocks wind effectively for temperature regulation
  • Reasonable Price Point: Less expensive than premium ultralight alternatives
  • Helmet Compatible Hood: Works with climbing and cycling helmets

Cons

  • Poor Breathability: No ventilation options, becomes clammy quickly
  • Wets Out Easily: DWR coating fails quickly, especially in sustained rain
  • Uncomfortable Interior: Sticky, plasticky feel against skin
  • High Maintenance: Requires frequent DWR reapplication
  • Limited Durability: Thin fabric susceptible to abrasion and punctures
  • Restrictive Fit: Trim cut limits layering options
  • No Pit Zips: Cannot dump heat during activity

The Bottom Line

The Helium Rain Jacket excels in specific scenarios—emergency weather protection, weight-critical applications, and dry climates with occasional precipitation. However, it struggles as an all-purpose rain jacket due to breathability and durability limitations. Success depends on matching expectations with appropriate use cases.

Best Alternatives

If the Helium Rain Jacket's limitations concern you, several alternatives offer different trade-offs between weight, comfort, and performance. Here are the top options based on extensive field testing and user feedback.

Montbell Versalite ($260)

Weight: 5.8oz | Best For: Ultralight enthusiasts prioritizing breathability

The Versalite represents the pinnacle of ultralight rain jacket design. At nearly an ounce lighter than the Helium, it features pit zips and significantly better breathability thanks to its Gore-Tex Windstopper Infinium membrane. However, the 10-denier fabric is extremely fragile.

Check Montbell Versalite Price

Compared to the helium 2 rain jacket, the Versalite offers superior comfort but requires more careful handling.

Rab Downpour Light ($165)

Weight: 7.1oz | Best For: Comfort-focused ultralight hiking

The Downpour Light addresses the Helium's comfort issues with a soft, textured interior lining that feels pleasant against skin. While slightly heavier, it offers superior breathability and a more comfortable wearing experience during extended use.

Check Rab Downpour Light Price

The helium ii rain jacket predecessor had similar comfort issues that the Downpour Light successfully addresses.

Patagonia Torrentshell 3L ($149)

Weight: 12.9oz | Best For: All-around durability and value

If you can accept the weight penalty, the Torrentshell offers significantly better durability, pit zips for ventilation, and reliable waterproofing. It's the go-to choice for hikers who prioritize function over weight savings.

Check Torrentshell 3L Price

For those considering outdoor research helium rain pants, Patagonia's matching Torrentshell pants offer better durability.

OR Foray ($199)

Weight: 13.4oz | Best For: Serious weather protection

From the same manufacturer, the Foray represents what the Helium could be with durability as a priority. Gore-Tex construction, pit zips, and robust fabric make this ideal for harsh conditions where the Helium would fail.

Check OR Foray Price

The men's helium rain jacket and women's helium rain jacket serve different needs than this more robust option.

Choosing the Right Alternative

  • For maximum weight savings: Montbell Versalite (if you can handle fragile fabric)
  • For comfort without huge weight penalty: Rab Downpour Light
  • For all-around performance: Patagonia Torrentshell 3L
  • For serious weather: OR Foray or Arc'teryx Beta AR

Frequently Asked Questions

Is the Outdoor Research Helium Rain Jacket truly waterproof?

The Helium Rain Jacket uses Pertex Shield Diamond Fuse 2.5-layer fabric that is technically waterproof with fully sealed seams. However, many users report it wets out quickly in sustained rain due to DWR coating failure and thin fabric construction. It's best viewed as water-resistant for light precipitation rather than fully waterproof for heavy, prolonged rain. Regular maintenance with DWR treatments like Nikwax Tech Wash is essential for maintaining performance. The jacket performs well in brief showers but struggles in multi-hour rain events or high-humidity conditions where condensation becomes problematic.

How much does the Helium Rain Jacket weigh?

The men's version weighs approximately 6.8 ounces (193g) in size large, while the women's version is slightly lighter at 6.3 ounces (179g). This makes it one of the lightest fully waterproof jackets available, though alternatives like the Montbell Versalite are even lighter at 5.8 ounces. The weight varies slightly between color options and sizes, with smaller sizes obviously weighing less. For ultralight backpackers counting every ounce, this weight savings can be significant over long distances, potentially saving 6-10 ounces compared to traditional rain jackets like the Patagonia Torrentshell 3L.

What's the difference between Helium and Helium II jackets?

The Helium II was the previous generation that used different fabric and construction. The current Helium Rain Jacket (2020+) features updated Pertex Shield Diamond Fuse 2.5L fabric, improved durability, and refined fit. The newer version addresses some durability concerns but retains the ultra-lightweight design philosophy of the original. Key improvements include better seam construction, more durable zipper pulls, and slightly updated sizing. However, fundamental limitations like poor breathability and DWR maintenance requirements remain consistent across generations. Some users report the newer version has slightly better initial waterproofing but similar long-term performance characteristics.

Is the Helium Rain Jacket good for thru-hiking?

The Helium Rain Jacket has mixed reviews for thru-hiking. While many ultralight hikers appreciate its packability and weight savings, others report durability issues and poor performance in sustained rain. It's better suited for desert sections or areas with intermittent precipitation rather than consistently wet climates like the Pacific Northwest or New England. Successful thru-hikers often pair it with other rain gear options, using the Helium for dry sections and switching to more robust shells for wet regions. The jacket's limited breathability makes it challenging for high-output hiking, and the thin fabric may not withstand months of daily use and abrasion from pack straps and vegetation.

What are the best alternatives to the Helium Rain Jacket?

Top alternatives include the Montbell Versalite (lighter with pit zips), Rab Downpour Light (more comfortable interior), and Patagonia Torrentshell 3L (more durable but heavier). For serious weather protection, consider the OR Foray or Arc'teryx Beta AR, though these sacrifice the ultra-light advantage. The choice depends on your priorities: if weight is paramount and you can accept fragility, the Montbell Versalite offers superior breathability. If comfort matters more than a few ounces, the Rab Downpour Light provides better next-to-skin feel. For all-around versatility and durability, the Torrentshell 3L remains hard to beat despite the weight penalty. Each alternative addresses different weaknesses of the Helium while introducing their own trade-offs.

Final Verdict

After extensive testing and analysis, the Outdoor Research Helium Rain Jacket emerges as a highly specialized piece of gear that excels in specific applications while falling short as an all-purpose solution. Understanding this distinction is crucial for making an informed purchasing decision.

Who Should Buy the Helium Rain Jacket

  • Ultralight backpackers in dry climates who need emergency weather protection
  • Alpine climbers requiring lightweight, packable insurance against sudden storms
  • Trail runners and fastpackers needing minimal weight backup protection
  • Desert hikers dealing with occasional thunderstorms and temperature swings
  • Weekend warriors in moderate climates seeking basic rain protection

Who Should Look Elsewhere

  • Hikers in wet climates like the Pacific Northwest or Appalachians
  • Those prioritizing comfort during extended wear periods
  • Backpackers on tight budgets who can't afford frequent gear replacement
  • High-output activities requiring excellent breathability
  • Anyone seeking a durable, long-term rain jacket investment

The outdoor research helium ii rain jacket represents a clear evolution toward the current model, but fundamental trade-offs remain unchanged. If you can work within the Helium's limitations and maintain it properly, it offers compelling advantages for weight-conscious outdoor enthusiasts.

My recommendation after two years of testing: consider the Helium if ultralight weight is your primary concern and you understand its limitations. However, most hikers will be better served by spending slightly more on alternatives like the Rab Downpour Light or accepting the weight penalty of the Patagonia Torrentshell 3L for superior all-around performance.
